newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: SFE wheat rises in distant contracts on India deal.
newsitem.headline: SFE wheat rises in distant contracts on India deal.

text.p: The Australian Wheat Board's sale of a further one million tonnes of wheat to India supported Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) new crop wheat futures on Friday.
Two contracts traded, with May 1997 steady on A$185.00 a tonne and January 1988 up by A$2.50 to A$175.00 on 17 lots.
Settlement prices in more distant contracts rose well, by up to A$4.00 a tonne.

Chris Gray of C,A & L Bell Commodities Corp Pty Ltd noted the bulk of the Indian contract would be delivered in November/December from new crop wheat, although 250,000 tonnes for July/August would be from the current crop.
"It's pretty supportive for the new crop. The old crop at the moment is pretty tight and another 250,000 tonnes going out is pretty supportive as well," he said.
Gray said he believed the January contract in particular would attract more volume in coming days. "I think the strength will continue there for the short-term," he said.

The rising Chicago market was unlikely to affect SFE wheat for a couple of weeks until the U.S. weather situation was clarified. But with potential upside in the U.S., it would not surprise if further strength eventuated, he said.
